habitat_description:
A. gentilis nests and forages in forests with high canopy cover, regardless of composition (Austin, 1993; Hargis et al., 1994; Squires and Reynolds, 1997; Kimmel and Yahner, 1991; Boal et al., 2001; Greenwald et al., 2005).

The species avoids open areas (Lapinski, 2000), oak shrubland or grassland (Fischer, 1986), clearcuts, young stands (Greenwald et al., 2005), meadows (Austin, 1993), sagebrush (Hargis et al., 1994), and juniper woodlands (Johansson et al., 1994; Drennan and Beier, 2003). However, in the Great Basin, northern goshawks have been documented foraging in shrub steppe while nesting in fragmented aspen or lodgepole stands (Younk and Bechard, 1993; Hasselblad and Bechard, 2007). Hence the selection of Great Basin shrub and steppe ecological systems as auxiliary map units. The auxiliary buffer distance of 2000 m was derived from home ranges in this habitat published by Hasselblad and Bechard (2007).

Winter habitat is the same as summer with the addition of juniper woodlands (Squires and Ruggiero, 1995; Stevens, 2001; Drennan and Beier, 2003).
